comment.author: 44911068@N03
comment._content: Why are they marching with the Stars and Stripes in Ireland ???

comment._content:
We are the Boys Brigade,
Dressed up in marmalade,
Three ha'penny tuppenny pillbox
and a couple of yards of braid!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Used that be sung by the Boys' Brigade, or sung at them??

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: AT them of course and to the tune of their bugle salute!

comment.author: 77975599@N03
comment._content:
My question is the same as Marine Attack Squadron ( VMA ) 225; why was this crowd being led by 
"Old Glory,The American Stars and Bars"?

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77975599@N03] That's a very good question.  In one sense you need to understand the appeal of the US in Ireland and how your flag would have been perceived down through the years.  There is also the possibility that some US dignitary or delegation may have been in attendance but it just may be that there was a number of flags on display but the one that was captured was "Old Glory"?  Given their unionist roots I am sure that the Union Jack was in the centre out of shot or further out in front.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77975599@N03] Have done some more investigation in national and regional newspapers, but could find no further information about this event...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Would love to see a higher resolution copy of this. As to the the question of the Stars & stripes, Waterford has one important connection to the United States which is Thomas Francis Meagher. Meagher was a Brigadier General in the Union army and commander of the Irish Brigade in the American Civil war, he was also appointed acting governor of Montana after the war. A few years before this photo was taken the Thomas Francis Meagher fife & drum band was formed, I wonder if that could be the band in the photo. www.irishfreedom.net/Fenian%20graves/TF%20Meagher/TFMeagh...

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: There is another photo in the NLI catologue which looks like it was taken on the same occasion. The Stars & Stripes are again on display but there is an Irish Harp flag displayed on the right which would not have been the flag of choice for unionists and its interesting that there are no Union Jacks displayed in either photo. catalogue.nli.ie/Record/P_WP_0956/Image?lookfor=http://ww...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] I'd love to see a higher res version too, Paul. But that's from our Poole Imperial glass plates, and we don't have a high res to share.  :(

However, we do have a higher res of the other one above, so I'll post that for you... (Please nag me if you don't see it going up some time this week!)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Ha ha! GoogleCameras have been inside the little museum cottages where I am sometimes volunteer watchkeeper - Mid-North Coast Maritime Museum NSW a few months ago as an experiment. I find this tOtEs AmAzEbAllS to be able to poke around inside buildings from the comfort of my desk. In two years it will seem normal, and we'll complain when it doesn't work ... [apologies for digression]
